title: New York State Dams and Watershed Data
text:
This webpage highlights the important data regarding dams in New York State, sourced from various agencies and resources. The map below visualizes key data points about the dams in the state.




We have embedded an interactive ArcGIS Online map showcasing the dams in New York State. You can explore the map for further details on the dam locations and their attributes. For the purposes of this page, we’re highlighting key areas of interest such as the Long Island dams and their watershed impacts.








Below are the references to the datasets and sources used for creating the interactive map and analysis of New York State dams.

New York State Watersheds
New York State’s Department of Environmental Conservation provides a comprehensive list of watersheds and relevant environmental data. This dataset helps us understand the flow of water and its impact on the regions surrounding the dams.

New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (NYS DEC): Watersheds and Water Bodies

New York State Dams
The GIS data from New York State includes important details about the location and status of dams throughout the state. This data is crucial for tracking and analyzing the effects of dams on local ecosystems.

GIS Data from NYS: New York State Dams Dataset





This page provides an overview of New York State’s dams and related watershed data. By exploring the interactive map and the datasets provided, we can better understand the impact of these dams on the environment, wildlife, and communities in the state.

title: About Me
text:
I am passionate about preserving the natural beauty of Long Island, and my commitment to environmental conservation has been greatly shaped by my involvement with the Seatuck Environmental Association.
Seatuck is a nonprofit organization dedicated to safeguarding Long Island’s wildlife and natural resources, with a special focus on protecting wetlands, rivers, and coastal habitats. Through Seatuck, I’ve had the opportunity to actively contribute to conservation efforts, participate in habitat restoration projects, and advocate for sustainable practices.
Their mission aligns deeply with my values, as Seatuck works to address key environmental challenges such as habitat loss, water pollution, and climate change. The organization empowers individuals and communities through education, research, and hands-on involvement in environmental protection.
By supporting Seatuck’s efforts, I’ve gained a greater understanding of the importance of local ecosystems and the vital need for long-term environmental stewardship. I believe that together, we can make a real difference in preserving the natural resources that are so important to Long Island’s biodiversity and future.
Through my connection with Seatuck, I am more committed than ever to protecting our planet, fostering sustainability, and ensuring a healthier environment for future generations.

title: Rebuilding Dams in Suffolk County
text:
Preamble
Many dams on Long Island were built decades ago for industrial, agricultural, or recreational purposes. However, changing environmental conditions, aging infrastructure, and evolving water management strategies have raised questions about whether certain dams should be rebuilt after destruction.


Open Letter to County Executive
Dear County Executive Edward P. Romaine,
I am writing to urge careful reconsideration of the proposed dam reconstruction efforts at Stonybrook Mill Pond and Stump Pond. While I understand the intention to restore these structures, I believe this approach poses significant risks to Long Island’s ecological integrity and long-term sustainability.


Background
This project focuses on the dams at Mill Pond in Stony Brook, New York, and Stump Pond in Smithtown, New York, which were destroyed in a storm in August 2024. The dam at Mill Pond has historically provided aesthetic and recreational benefits, but concerns about sediment accumulation and ecological disruption have emerged. Similarly, Stump Pond, a prominent feature supporting diverse wildlife, also raises issues related to water quality and hydrological alteration.


Key Considerations

Environmental impact of rebuilding versus removal
Hydrological changes and water quality concerns
Effects on local wildlife and biodiversity
Economic implications for Suffolk County
Public and stakeholder interests
